Your search query about Władysław Reymont's "Chłopi" (The Peasants) and its influence on Polish writers and rural literature reveals a fascinating literary landscape. Władysław Stanisław Reymont (1867-1925) was a Polish novelist and the laureate of the 1924 Nobel Prize in Literature, with his best-known work being the award-winning four-volume novel Chłopi (The Peasants).

## Reymont's Revolutionary Approach to Rural Literature

The novel "Chłopi," honored with the Nobel Prize in 1924, stands as a monumental work by Władysław Stanisław Reymont, depicting the life of Polish countryside at the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries with extraordinary fidelity and artistic mastery. Reymont's work is an example of realism – the author recreates with extraordinary precision the appearance of the village, the language of peasants, their clothing, dishes, social relations, and ceremonies. The novel is distinguished primarily by its accurate and realistic presentation of the life of a rural community in 19th-century Poland.

The novel undoubtedly fits into the trend of fascination with the countryside and the life of peasant communities, particularly vibrant in 19th-century Polish literature. However, Reymont broke certain unwritten taboos with his novel. As literary scholar prof. Małgorzata Litwinowicz-Droździel said in an interview with PAP: The text of the episodes went through censorship, which cut two things – threads related to Polish history, which later appeared in the book edition, and moral threads, because "Chłopi" is a novel with a strong dose of eroticism.

## Literary Techniques and Naturalism

Reymont drew from naturalism in presenting the life of the community. One of the best examples of this type of work in Polish literature is the social-moral novel by Władysław Reymont "Chłopi". The existence of people shown in "Chłopi" is in accordance with the rhythm of the seasons, and changes in nature affected their types of work and ways of life. Their actions were primarily to ensure satisfaction of biological needs and the desire for possession, so they were a struggle for existence. In accordance with naturalistic concepts, Reymont's heroes were as they were shaped by their environment and possibilities.

## Relationship with Stefan Żeromski

The relationship between Reymont and Stefan Żeromski reveals interesting contrasts in approaches to rural themes. The view of the countryside in Reymont's and Żeromski's works is very different, which results from different authorial intentions of both authors. Stefan Żeromski, who was called the conscience of Poles, set himself the goal of showing his countrymen the most vital social, moral, and national problems and sought ways to solve them. He strove, as he put it in "Diaries," to "scratch Polish wounds so they wouldn't heal with a membrane of baseness," which is why in his works he showed the most extreme manifestations of misery, backwardness, degradation, or even bestialization prevailing in Polish countryside.

About two weeks before Reymont's death, another great Polish writer and Reymont's competitor for the Nobel – Stefan Żeromski – passed away. The creator of "Chłopi" wrote in a letter at that time: "Today Żeromski died, this is a cruel blow for me for many reasons... The loss to Polish literature is irreplaceable. I adored him as a genius writer".

Only a few years ago, after opening the Academy archives, we learned from the Nobel Committee protocols that Żeromski never had a chance for the prize, and in Reymont's case, only "Chłopi" were in play from the beginning. The researcher from UJK emphasized in conversation that Swedish academics considered Żeromski's prose, first – as politically involved, second – as artistically weak: too emotional, pessimistic, compositionally unsteady, confused, boring. The paradox is that all these features of the author of "Ludzie bezdomni" writing, which made him the spiritual leader of the entire generation – even several generations – of Polish intelligentsia, excluded him from the group of serious Nobel Prize candidates.

## Andrzej Strug and Political Literature

Andrzej Strug was a writer and publicist, freemason, activist of the socialist and independence movement, member of Bela, as well as a screenwriter. In 1893, Tadeusz Gałecki (Strug's real name) debuted with his excellent critical study on Stefan Żeromski, for which he received the first prize in the competition of the Scientific-Literary Association in Lviv. Slightly younger than Stefan Żeromski and Wacław Sieroszewski, he belonged to the oldest generation that participated in winning their own state.

While Strug's work focused more on political and social activism rather than rural themes specifically, he organized a rural propaganda school together with others and taught agitators: party intelligentsia, students, and more enlightened workers from rural backgrounds. In several conspiratorial apartments in Praga, the rural school was active for six hours a day.

## Maria Kuncewiczowa and Psychological Literature

"Cudzoziemka" by Maria Kuncewiczowa is a literary masterpiece that draws the reader into the depths of the human soul, to immerse there in the despair, pain, and sorrow of the main character, Róża Żabczyńska. It is a story about misfortune that interweaves with Polish history of interwar Poland. Among her most important works is certainly "Cudzoziemka" from 1936. This novel brought Kuncewiczowa the greatest fame. It tells the story of Róża, whose difficult relationships with loved ones marked by the loss of first love constitute the main narrative axis.

While Kuncewiczowa's work was more focused on psychological portraiture rather than rural themes, in works such as "Chłopi" by Władysław Reymont, music integrates the community and reflects the rural rhythm of life, while in "Cudzoziemka" by Maria Kuncewiczowa it shows the internal struggles of the main character.

## Legacy and Influence

The end of war meant the rebirth of statehood for countries enslaved by great European powers – at that time the independent Polish state returned to the map of Europe. This gave a strong creative impulse to writers aspiring to fulfill the role of cultural unification of the state previously divided by partitioners – Polish writers fulfilled this task with interest, especially S. Żeromski... like W. Reymont painting the colorful culture of Polish countryside.

In Poland, naturalism was represented among others by Władysław Reymont with his epic novel "Chłopi," for which he received the Nobel Prize. Gabriela Zapolska in the play "Moralność pani Dulskiej" criticized bourgeois hypocrisy, while Stefan Żeromski in "Ludzie bezdomni" showed the difficult life of lower social classes... Polish creators, including Władysław Reymont and Stefan Żeromski, introduced social themes into their works.

In conclusion, while Reymont's "Chłopi" established a new standard for depicting rural life in Polish literature, its influence on the mentioned writers varied considerably. Żeromski approached rural themes from a more critical social perspective, Strug focused on political activism that occasionally touched rural issues, and Kuncewiczowa concentrated on psychological portraiture rather than rural themes specifically. However, all these writers contributed to the rich tapestry of Polish literature that emerged in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, each bringing their unique perspective to understanding Polish society and culture.
